abstract: United States Department of Education data suggests that African-American students, especially boys, face much harsher discipline in public schools than other students and are three and a half times more likely to be suspended or expelled than their white peers; civil rights advocates bemoan findings, fearing the emergence of a pipeline from the classroom to prison for a growing number of students of color.
lead_paragraph: Overall, African-American students were three and a half times more likely to be suspended or expelled than their white peers.

headline.seo: Black Students Face More Harsh Discipline, Data Shows
headline.main: Black Students Face More Discipline, Data Suggests
